BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Snowpack is wet down to the ground
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanche danger is low. Main problem can be wet snow. Wet glide-snow avalanches can trigger naturally in steep terrain in all aspects, releases mostly small, occasionally medium-sized. In addition, on extremely steep rough and rocky slopes in all aspects, small wet loose-snow avalanches are possible, triggerable by winter sports enthusiasts in very steep terrain. Beware the risks of being swept along.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack surface is thoroughly moist, consists of melt-freeze forms atop the compact and stable snowpack, bonding well with the old snow but quickly becoming moist and forfeiting its firmness. The snowpack is often wet down to the ground. On steep slopes, gliding movements are the result. Below 1500 m, hardly any snow on the ground, even on north-facing slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Avalanche danger levels are not expected to change significantly.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Often trigger-prone snowdrift accumulations at high altitude
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanche danger is low. Main problem: wet snow. Wherever smooth grass-covered slopes still have sufficient snow, wet glide-snow avalanches can release at any time of day or night. Danger zones occur seldom but in all aspects at higher altitudes. Glide-snow avalanches are usually small, can also be triggered by winter sports enthusiasts as moist loose-snow slides in steep terrain, and can trigger naturally in steep rocky terrain. Slab avalanches (small-to-medium) can trigger in some places by 1 person. Danger zones occur in steep rigeline terrain on N/E/SE facing slopes and in wind-loaded gullies and bowls. Beware the dangers of taking a fall.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack surface is thoroughly moist, freezes at night at high altitudes, where on shady slopes there is still powder to be found atop the compact and stable snowpack, bonding well with the old snow but quickly becoming moist and forfeiting its firmness. The snowpack is often wet down to the ground. On steep slopes, gliding movements are the result. Below 1500 m, hardly any snow on the ground, even on north-facing slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Depending on amounts of precipitation, avalanche danger levels could rise somewhat.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Up above, snowdrift accumulations, down below wet snow
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanche danger m is moderate. Main problem: wet snow. Wherever smooth grass-covered slopes still have sufficient snow, wet glide-snow avalanches can release at any time of day or night. Danger zones occur seldom but in all aspects at higher altitudes. Glide-snow avalanches are usually small, can also be triggered by winter sports enthusiasts as moist loose-snow slides in steep terrain, and can trigger naturally in steep rocky terrain. Slab avalanches (small-to-medium) can trigger in some places by 1 person. Danger zones occur in steep rigeline terrain on N/E/SE facing slopes and in wind-loaded gullies and bowls. Beware the dangers of taking a fall.

The snowpack is often wet down to the ground. On steep slopes, gliding movements are the result. Below 1500 m, hardly any snow on the ground, even on north-facing slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Avalanche danger levels are not expected to change significantly.
